UCGOozZLe6PBlHmQBuSgQg.text: Good news: The chicken's great! My favourite was the soy chicken wings, but the others were pretty good too. Crispy outside, moist inside. I don't have much to carp about on the food front.Bad news: The service is awful. 2 servers on a Sunday night sounds ok for a small eatery, right? Problem is, they're forgetful. We didn't get our drinks till after the chicken arrived, and only because I asked. The 2nd round of drinks was also forgotten. 2 tables away, it emerged that they hadn't gotten their chicken because the server thought that they were having the chicken buffet option (they weren't, although I fail to see how that should affect their food service). Salad is supposed to be complimentary. We got none. When I asked (presumably the owner),  he said pretty apologetically that they were probably out. Dude. First, you're open till 2am, and it wasn't even 10pm yet. Secondly, why did we have to ASK to hear that you were out of salad? It should have been said upfront.In sum: If there's another voucher-type deal, we might go again, but otherwise, I'd be willing to pay more for less forgetful and sloppy service.

cs6ebI8Kk_EJB_9KawbMDg.text: Nice wings!! Everybody comes here for wings! We ordered the cheesy squid stew to go with the wings. Not bad a choice. Very apetitizing. The spiciness is a bit bland, so next time I will ask for more spiciness. Paid before 7.30pm and get 20% off.

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Cheesy stew!
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Wings!

J5heKH1amPwNie4Q8mBxDg.text: One of the best Korean dinners we've ever had. Located in K-town in Singapore, this place is among many other Korean restaurants in the area. The restaurant was a little tight but the atmosphere and energy were great. We ordered a watermelon soju, japchae, dry spicy noodles, chicken wings, and bulgogi fries. Hands down the best things were the wings and fries! The flavors were amazing, plus we got to wash everything down with the watermelon soju, which we really recommend ordering with your dinner (if only for the instagram pic ) Prices are typical for Singapore. Great place for dinner or even for late night snacking.

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Fried chicken wings
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Bulgogi fries
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Restaurant facade

Rq0fKQSGax_4OEl47KmocA.text: Everyone here is so cheerful and friendly! I'm in a rush so just order takeout. The smell of their food is so good I want to come back again!! Guess what?!! They just served me watermelon smoothie because my food is not ready yet! This place didn't cease to amaze me!!I'll be back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. The takeaway bag is so nice!!
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Top foods

EWOg3UT5JVaPAqoQp4eADg.text: My favourite place for fried chicken wings - I adore their soya chicken wings which are perfectly fried to a crisp while remaining moist. They also serve several other variations of fried chicken but really, why waste your calories when the soya one is the most awesome. It is a little pricey at 12 bucks for 4 chicken wings but I think it's very much worth it. We also ordered the bulgogi fries and tteokbokki cheese and seafood stew. The fries was tasty with beef that wasn't overly cooked. The stew was a tad too sweet and spicy for my liking. The watermelon soju was interesting but taste wise I think it's mediocre. I tried to make reservations an hour before I arrived and the staff curtly told told me to just show up because reservations are not necessary. When I arrived, the place was full. So that was rather annoying. Emil was friendly and offered recommendations because he thought we may have ordered too much for our party of 3. Unfortunately, it was a little off putting when he insisted we write a review on FB and show him before letting us leave. He did make up for it with a 1-for-1 voucher for dessert but it did mar my impression of the place. Multiple outlets exist but I've only visited this branch.

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore

J1TEVUuoCAVMHc6HTeW1Ng.text: Went there with friend. Tried their boneless chicken, seafood topokki and watermelon soju.1. Service: it was great. The food was served less than 15 mins after we place order2. Environment: good place for gathering but it's slightly too dim... 3. Food: the boneless chicken fried with rice cake in sweet and spicy sauce. Something look totally different from the photo in the menu. But it was great. While seafood topokki, I counted it was only 4 rice cake... 4 rice cakes for $20.... I am not really happy about it. 4. Drink: the watermelon juice is diluted with water, not premium type of soju... And it cost $38!!

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Seafood topokki
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Boneless chicken

lnYesOxqjoRBWDJMINmqAQ.text: If you want to save a bit (20% off food bill), settle your bill and leave by 730pm. I think it is quite a good incentive for diners to eat and go instead of lingering and chatting among themselves long after the food is gone, and a big crowd is waiting outside for a table. Having read about the crowd if you go at the usual dinner time, we decided to go early and arrived around 6pm. The place was already half filled by then. At around 7pm, there was a line of people waiting for a table and it was only a Monday night. Having spied the early bird special of getting 20% off, we decided to try to leave by 730pm and let others have our table. A feat as we had two friends who only arrived close to 7pm and had just 30 minutes to finish the food. They ran out of the watermelon shell for the watermelon soju so we skipped that. Instead we tried the corn cheese which was really just average. A bit too creamy and cheesy that it was quite jelat (very rich) after a while and it was already shared by 4. The ganjang chicken wings (soy sauce) were really good and I must say I prefer the wings to the actual fried chicken pieces. The fried chicken were cut into 4 pieces and the breast meat was a bit on the dry side and not that enjoyable after a while. It would be worse if you did not order the chicken with any sauce. We had spicy up (not that spicy after all) and yangnyum up (like sweet and sour sauce with a bit of spice). The skin was crispy and delicious and the meat (except breast meat) moist and tender.I think 4 diners are just the right group size to try 2 different types of fried chicken and a side of chicken wings as you get 2 chicken pieces and a chicken wing. It may be different if you are very hungry or have a group of guys. The buffet is still available though they limit a 2 hour window for that.

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Buffet info. 2 hours limit.
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Operating hours

ee0rPK-f9g695eCE6k56dQ.text: Who doesn't love a good fried chicken? Ever since my first taste of Korean fried chicken at Mad for Chicken in NYC (they go by a diff name Tt escapes my pre-caffeinated brain now), I've been longing for those robust and exhilarating flavors again.The search ends at Chicken Up. Exceptionally tender and juicy chicken with a light and superbly crispy batter. BonChon can screw its double fried a** staleness that it claims to be authentic. Yes I'm still darn pissed about Tt crappy chicken that I had there a yr ago at the Bugis+ outlet. Anyway, their mild up spicy isn't that spicy to me so i'll go for suicide chicken next time. I absolutely went gaga over the soya chicken. My gawd. Droolicious I tell ya! First time trying the Andong chicken stew and my.. It was such a silent killer. Be very careful eating this one. I didn't pay attention and a little of the soup went down the wrong pipe and I was coughing and tearing for a long time. That said, it's actually not outrightly spicy if you are careful. Well flavored chicken that falls off the bone. They also have the glass noodles in them.Chicken lovers, this is the place to be! They do a chicken buffet with a beer option. Do check them out!

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Best Korean fried chicken in Singapore!!

WauM2D3hx0_Rw70uaxqyxg.text: I'm going to have to disagree with the other reviewers here. While this place is billed as serving Korean style fried chicken, I felt like I was eating a Korean-inspired promotional item from KFC, at a Kko Kko Na Ra price.Yes, the chicken pieces were large and generous. But the quality of the batter was lacking and the crispiness didn't keep well. The sauces didn't deliver the same punch as Kko Kko Na Ra's or 4 Fingers's.

F-_xLh8QiiMjLs1l3LGmGg.text: FRIED CHEEEEKEN!!!!!!!Just 2 of us for dinner today and certainly over ordered. Started off with fries - scratch that a humongous pile of fries. It was tossed with a good serving of kimchi - great combi to the super crispy fries. Shoved it all the carbs down with servings of yakult soju (no surprises here - it's just soju + yakult).Ordered wings, 4 of them - can't remember what it's called but the wings were generously glazed with something syrupy and sprinkled with sesame seeds. So much glaze, so crispyyyy.Main dish was 1/2 chicken (cut into 4 pieces) of spicy cheeken. Supposedly Chicken Up's highlight and I vouched for their recommendation! How do they make it so tasty and crispy!?

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Yakult Soju

AjAsndZpda3qVhj5MzHCgQ.text: When an #overrated food met an #overpriced reality, disappointment emerges. Only at Chicken Up, Tanjong Pagar. Go there to experience #lousy #service as a bonus.#chickenup #chicken #up #tanjongpagar #tanjong #pagar #singapore #dreadful #badfood

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. This is when restaurant has a good publicity but with bad food.

7JAAoVuGKPjTeE_4zF-MAQ.text: Very nice and tasty fried chickens!!Ordered two types of chicken wings and it came out big portion with 4 pcs each portion. The chicken wing superb!!I see everybody was ordering watermelon soju. With $38 priceetag that is pricey and although it was special, but i dont think it is good enough. Drank two glasses and let it go wasted 3/4 of the watermelon soju. So next time will order their desert with ice cream instead of their popular watermelon soju!!

PgOh7FgZO5gISqOqhaCqBQ.text: Really its 4.5 stars. Rejoice! I think I have found my go-to drinking and KFC place on the island. The variety, the vibe, and the sheer portions of the chicken is indeed one up from the rest.The moment you walk into Chicken Up, you feel this warmth about the place- Kpop featured on the big screen, beer and soju all around, call buttons for service... this feels a bit like home (Ktown LA). Simulated and having the concept of "rounds" when partying in Korea, I believe that Chicken Up is perfect for "Ee-Cha" (2nd round- more drinking and noshing on snacks) before heading out for Karaoke. Something that Singaporeans should really start adapting to.Lets get on with the food, shall we?Original Fried Chicken: Amazing. The skin is fried perfectly and well seasoned, while the meat is super juicy and moist. Honestly delicious. It takes me back to the ones in Korea.I don't even know why real KFC or Popeye's exist when you can have this chicken. Seriously, one of the best.Soy Chicken Wings: Also a delicious marinade. 4 wings, large and meaty with ample soy garlic. Very delicious.Sweet & Spicy Chicken: A bit too sweet for my liking, was hoping to have a bit more kick, but equally delicious.  They also serve a "popcorn chicken" version of this sauce the comes boneless. **Tip for all you Americanized people- this is the closest to Orange Chicken you will get in Singapore. Screw Panda Express, Chicken Up's popcorn chicken + a bowl of rice may very well be my go-to meal at least once a week. It's THAT good.**Odeng Tang (Fishcake soup): I was feeling a bit under the weather but the spicy broth hit the spot.  The portion of fishcake was VERY generous.Cheese Corn: Gooey, Rich, Creamy- honestly perfect for beer.Truffle Fries: Ample seasoning, good portion for sharing.Beverages: Korean drinks, Hite, Soju, Draft, Asahi, Maggoli, you name it, they have it. Outstanding.Only downfall- the radish cubes were not marinated as well as I liked it to be, but this is a very minor detail.so, why come to Chicken Up? 3 reasons.1. $25 AYCE Chicken Dinner, with $15 AYCD Beer top up. Best deal in town. Perfect for guys2. Perfect place to unwind with your friends, snack, nosh, and catch up on Kpop3. Large and delicious portions and a good variety of Anju (Korean Tapas) Now all they need is a noribang next door and my Ktown experience would be complete here in Singapore.

photos.caption: Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Popcorn Chicken. AMAZING!!!! I am craving this right now.
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Sweet & Spicy Chicken
Photo of Chicken Up - Singapore, Singapore. Soy Garlic Wings

Dwr2tAgcW2K01UPrkdHTbw.text: Routinely one of the busiest restaurants in tanjong pagar (even on weekdays), Chicken Up brings us a simple menu built round its infamous fried chicken combined with a great environment and friendly staff. The Ganjang (garlic soya) was the first of its kind for me and it never disappoints.

0efsGamXLZ-wwn-UP_YGrA.text: All I can say is if a) you're super hungry after work b) you love fried chicken, approach Chicken Up with caution. The dude and I are not buffet people. We took the buffet because it made sense to pay $25 to try a few flavors since even though he's half Korean, we both had no idea what Yamyung (?) or Andong stew was. Not being buffet people, we were therefore also set on just enjoying a slow meal, appreciating the flavors and talking instead of trying to cram as much food as possible down our gut.Here's the problem.The fried chicken here is really, really good. I would say it ranks second or slightly on par with No. 5's har cheong gai in terms of fried chicken execution. Very crisp on the outside even after the chicken has cooled, ridiculously juicy on the inside. We had the soy sauce, spicy, curry and popcorn flavors and then a stew each. The stew is quite light and we love the kick from the chillis bouncing off the sweet sauce.Ended up eating way too fast, probably too much and we were very full. Happy too. The "truffle" fries (there's really sparse specks of truffle shavings in the salt) were nothing to scream about but they were well fried too. The salad was wilted. But you're not there for these sides.Next time I visit it's probably going to be Hite beer + wings.Oh boy.

LxhGncgKYGRJuUgvg1EZkg.text: We wandered into Chicken Up on a lark as it was one of the only places still open when the hunger instinct hit one Friday night, but we wound up swearing to return, and soon!Due to the late hour, we erred on the side of over-ordering, although to be fair, the outcome would probably have been the same at the normal dinner bell.We decided on some Korean beer, the mild original fried chicken, the popcorn chicken, the cheesy corn and an order of truffle fries.  Everything was delicious, but it was the cheesy corn ($15) that upped the table tension.  El Queso Grande and I took one look at the hot cast iron surface with sizzling sweet corn and melty cheese and God only know what other fatty and tasty additives (I suspect butter and mayo) and IT WAS ON!  Jealously, we eyed one another's progress as we grimly munched and marched towards the exact center line of the sizzling plate, our taste buds writhing in ecstasy.The truffle fries were also quite incredible, easily the best fries I've ever had at a chicken joint.  We asked and got some Japanese mayo, which made it even better.  Each fry was perfectly crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside...we fervently hope that they come that way each and every time.The popcorn chicken ($20) was good...as another reviewer mentioned, it's the closest you get to an orange or sesame chicken in Singapore.  We found the mild original chicken to be decent, but we are looking forward to trying some of the other varieties next time.PARTING THOUGHT: We can't wait to go back for more of that cheesy corn!

iWz0JNSUEms8JiVkEYOCBg.text: This place is delicious. I went with friends and we did the all you can eat, and just went with the flavors that were suggested to us. The chicken was perfectly fried to order, all the sauces were super flavorful, and the chicken was juicy. Throw in sides, which you should try not too eat too much of because... CHICKEN. Just be prepared to feel fat and disgusting afterwards.Worth it.

Bd-CB4ZelZh5AdjZ_YzuZQ.text: Loved the watermelon soju! Refreshing... I could drink buckets of that stuff. The fried chicken was so tasty. Juicy and crispy. That's how I like it. My fave was the original crispy fried chicken. That was the tastiest. The spicy fried chicken was alright. Not especially spicy nor flavorful. I recommend getting the original rather than the spicy. The soy fried chick was yummy too.Go for the buffet at your own peril. We walked out of there feeling really sick. Really really sick and swearing off fried chicken for the next few months or year. That's because the chicken cuts are pretty big. Like KFC size pieces. So it's not the same as eating wings elsewhere. Go slow... And pace yourself. They took really long serving our chicken so we stuffed our faces with those oily bits and were so happy until that feeling kicked in. Also go for the cheese corn. It could have been more sizzling but it was delicious even unsizzled. Enjoy!

mEnv4v92UnGvYs_Nfs_KwA.text: A Vegetarian's Point of View Came here with fried chicken eating friends and had low expectations on my eating options. Surprisingly, there was stuff for me to eat and the chicken smelled and looked really good!The place doesnt look very welcoming from the street but dont let it fool you, the inside is warm, the staff is friendly and their is Girl Generation k-pop playing on a continuous loop. Food-wise, the chicken were huge pieces, kinda like the friend chicken from home where the chickens are genetically engineered. never seen chicken so big in Singapore before. What they call 'Popcorn Chicken' was really the Americanized Orange Chicken from Panda Express only bigger. Looked delicious even though i didnt eat it.Ended up getting the Cheese Corn (fairly good), the salad (good) and the truffle fries (really good). All the portions are huge so bring your appetitive

-vdAPlpGdhfQ_loBTKAkdA.text: Call me a fat slob but you cant really go wrong with copious amounts of beer and fried chicken. And that's what you get at the aptly named Chicken Up! - a popular fried chicken outlet from Korea.First, lets talk about the beer. On the menu is something called Suicide Beer. It is essentially a 1-litre mug of Heineken draught. Yep, 1-litre! Not difficult to understand why I like the place, eh? On to the food. Not your usual traditional Korean fare and not quite KFC. One of the side dishes is actually steamed Korean dumplings which are light and delightful, an excellent contrast to the fried chicken. All patrons also gets served free salad and pickles the moment you place your orders. Definitely good to partake in a little greens before the unhealthy stuff.  The chicken is served spicy or spicier, Korean chilli style! Crispier than crisp on the outside; soft, juicy and tender on the inside. Recently, South Korea's plans for world domination through the incredibly formulaic yet insanely infectious kpop has been gathering pace at an alarming rate. One fortunate by-product is Chicken Up ending up on our shores. This tiny eatery is everything Korean down to their staff, most of the regulars and the insanely annoying yet addictive kpop tunes and programmes broadcasting on their tv. Definitely not one for people who cant stand the kpop phenomenon and prices are more restaurant side than fast food eatery.

cU_qxGlzNe1k7S3aRC4PQw.text: Hard to find much to complain about here- the chicken was excellent with a wide variety, and the beer kept flowing, even if it was not great beer. A fantastic price if you want to eat an insane amount of chicken.
